choices.text: Molecular testing for gene mutations
Transfuse packed red blood cells and platelets

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with pancytopenia and a bone marrow biopsy revealing trilineage dysplasia. Cytogenetic analysis shows a normal karyotype. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in the workup?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Molecular testing for gene mutations

 

Option B:

 

In patients with MDS and a normal karyotype, molecular testing for gene mutations is recommended to confirm the diagnosis, assess prognosis, and guide treatment decisions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Repeat bone marrow biopsy: Repeat bone marrow biopsy is not necessary if the initial biopsy is diagnostic.

 

Option C. Start treatment with erythropoietin: Erythropoietin is used to treat anemia in MDS, but it is not a diagnostic test.

 

Option D. Transfuse packed red blood cells and platelets: Transfusion support may be needed, but it is not the next step in the diagnostic workup.

 

Educational objective:

 

Molecular testing for gene mutations is essential for the accurate diagnosis and management of MDS, especially in cases with a normal karyotype.

choices.text: MDS is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder.
Most patients with MDS will eventually progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
The risk of transformation to AML is higher in patients with complex karyotype abnormalities.
Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is the only curative option for MDS.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most patients with MDS will eventually progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Option B:

 

While MDS can transform into AML, the majority of patients do not progress to AML. The risk of transformation depends on several factors, including the subtype of MDS and the presence of cytogenetic abnormalities.

 

Educational objective:

 

Not all MDS patients progress to AML, and the prognosis varies depending on several factors.

questions.text: Which of the following morphological features on a peripheral blood smear is LEAST likely to be seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypersegmented neutrophils

 

Option D:

 

Hypersegmented neutrophils are more characteristic of megaloblastic anemias caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly (hypolobulated neutrophils): This is a classic finding in MDS, reflecting the dysplasia (abnormal maturation) of the myeloid lineage. Neutrophils may have bilobed or unsegmented nuclei.

 

Option B. Ring sideroblasts: These are red blood cells with iron deposits arranged in a ring around the nucleus, often seen in MDS, especially in cases with sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Howell-Jolly bodies: These are nuclear remnants in red blood cells, indicating impaired splenic function or dyserythropoiesis, both of which can be seen in MDS.

 

Educational objective:

 

MDS is characterized by dysplastic changes in various blood cell lines, but hypersegmented neutrophils are not typically seen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and easy bruising. Peripheral blood smear shows macrocytic anemia and dysplastic neutrophils. Cytogenetic analysis reveals a deletion in the long arm of chromosome 5 (del(5q)). According to the IPSS-R, what is the patient's prognostic risk category?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low

 

Option B:

 

The presence of del(5q) is associated with a good prognosis in MDS, and the patient's age and blood count findings suggest a lower-risk disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Very Low: While del(5q) MDS is a lower-risk subtype, it doesn't fall into the "very low" category, which is usually reserved for patients with very few cytopenias and no cytogenetic abnormalities.

 

Option C. Intermediate: This category typically includes patients with more cytopenias or less favorable cytogenetic findings than those with isolated del(5q).

 

Option D. High: These categories are reserved for MDS with a high risk of progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is not typical of isolated del(5q). These patients usually have excess blasts in the bone marrow, complex karyotypes, or specific genetic mutations associated with worse outcomes.

 

Educational objective:

 

Del(5q) is a favorable cytogenetic abnormality in MDS associated with a better prognosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with an isolated deletion in chromosome 7 (del(7q)). Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supportive care

 

Option D:

 

Isolated del(7q) in MDS is associated with a poor prognosis, and currently, there are no specific targeted therapies available for this subtype. Supportive care, including transfusions and growth factors, remains the mainstay of treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lenalidomide: Lenalidomide is a targeted therapy specifically approved for MDS with isolated del(5q), not del(7q). It is not effective in patients with del(7q) MDS.

 

Option B. Azacitidine: Azacitidine is a hypomethylating agent used for higher-risk MDS, but it has not shown significant benefit in patients with isolated del(7q).

 

Option C. Decitabine: Similar to azacitidine, decitabine is another hypomethylating agent used in higher-risk MDS and is not a specific treatment for del(7q).

 

Educational objective:

 

Supportive care is the primary treatment for MDS with isolated del(7q).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of headache, dizziness, and erythromelalgia (burning pain in the hands and feet). Her complete blood count (CBC) shows a platelet count of 950,000/µL. Given likely diagnosis, which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with essential thrombocythemia (ET)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JAK2 V617F

 

Option A:

 

JAK2 V617F is the most common driver mutation in ET, occurring in approximately 50-60% of cases. CALR and MPL mutations are also found in ET, but less frequently.

 

Educational objective:

 

JAK2 V617F mutation is a key diagnostic and prognostic marker in ET.

choices.text: Transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

questions.text: A patient with Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

ET patients are at increased risk for both thrombotic and bleeding complications due to abnormal platelet function. Additionally, there is a small risk of transformation to AML over time.

 

Educational objective:

 

ET requires careful monitoring and management to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with primary myelofibrosis (PMF)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JAK2 V617F

 

Option A:

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is present in approximately 50-60% of PMF cases and is a driver mutation in the pathogenesis of the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL1: This mutation is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

Option C. CALR and Option D. MPL: These mutations are also found in PMF but are less common than JAK2 V617F.

 

Educational objective:

 

JAK2 V617F is the most common mutation in PMF and can have prognostic implications.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, early satiety, and abdominal discomfort. Physical examination reveals massive splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows teardrop cells, nucleated red blood cells, and giant platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary myelofibrosis (PMF)

 

Option D:

 

PMF is characterized by bone marrow fibrosis, extramedullary hematopoiesis (leading to the presence of immature blood cells in the peripheral smear), and massive splenomegaly. Teardrop cells are a hallmark finding in PMF.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML): CML presents with leukocytosis and a left shift but not typically with teardrop cells or marked splenomegaly.

 

Option B. Polycythemia vera (PV): PV is characterized by elevated red blood cell mass, not fibrosis or teardrop cells.

 

Option C. Essential thrombocythemia (ET): ET presents with isolated thrombocytosis, not the constellation of findings seen in this patient.

 

Educational objective:

 

Teardrop cells, nucleated red blood cells, giant platelets, and massive splenomegaly are key features of PMF.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used to differentiate between ALL and AML?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

 

Option B:

 

MPO is a lysosomal enzyme present in myeloid cells but absent in lymphoid cells. It stains positive in AML blasts but negative in ALL blasts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS): PAS stains glycogen and mucopolysaccharides and is used to identify lymphoid blasts in ALL.

 

Option C. Sudan Black B (SBB): SBB stains lipids and is positive in AML blasts.

 

Option D. Nonspecific esterase (NSE): NSE stains esterases and is used to identify monocytic cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

MPO staining is a valuable tool for differentiating between AML and ALL based on the presence or absence of myeloperoxidase in blast cells.

choices.text: Auer rods on peripheral smear

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fatigue, pallor, fever, and bone pain. Peripheral blood smear shows blasts. Which of the following laboratory findings is more suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) than acute myeloid leukemia (AML)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) positivity

 

Option B:

 

TdT is a marker of immature lymphoid cells and is positive in more than 95% of ALL cases, while it's usually absent in AML.

 

Educational objective:

 

TdT positivity strongly suggests ALL.

questions.text: A patient newly diagnosed with APL is started on all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). Within two weeks, they develop fever, dyspnea, and pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Differentiation syndrome (APL differentiation syndrome)

 

Option A:

 

Differentiation syndrome is a unique complication of ATRA therapy in APL, characterized by fever, respiratory distress, and pulmonary infiltrates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tumor lysis syndrome: This is a metabolic complication that can occur in rapidly proliferating malignancies after chemotherapy. It is characterized by electrolyte abnormalities like hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia, along with acute kidney injury. These features are not typically seen in differentiation syndrome.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism: While pulmonary infiltrates are seen in both differentiation syndrome and pulmonary embolism, the patient's recent initiation of ATRA therapy makes differentiation syndrome more likely. Pulmonary embolism would typically present with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain and hypoxia.

 

Option D. Pneumonia: Pneumonia is a possible differential diagnosis, but the temporal association with ATRA initiation and the absence of typical infectious symptoms (cough, sputum production) makes differentiation syndrome more likely.

 

Educational objective:

 

Differentiation syndrome is a serious but manageable complication of ATRA in APL.

choices.text: ATRA + ATO + Chemotherapy

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with fatigue, bruising, and bleeding gums. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypergranular promyelocytes with Auer rods. Which combination therapy is MOST appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ATRA + ATO + Chemotherapy

 

Option D:

 

The presence of hypergranular promyelocytes with Auer rods indicates Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL). The most effective treatment for APL is combination therapy with All-Trans Retinoic Acid (ATRA), Arsenic Trioxide (ATO), and chemotherapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ATRA + Hydroxyurea: Hydroxyurea is a cytoreductive agent used in other types of leukemia, but it is not effective for APL. The combination of ATRA and hydroxyurea is not the standard of care.

 

Option B. ATO + Cytarabine: While both ATO and cytarabine are used in the treatment of APL, they are not typically used together without ATRA. ATRA is crucial for inducing differentiation of leukemic cells and preventing differentiation syndrome.

 

Option C. ATRA + ATO: This combination is highly effective in APL, but the addition of chemotherapy (usually an anthracycline like daunorubicin or idarubicin) further improves outcomes by targeting the leukemic cells directly.

 

Educational objective:

 

Combination therapy with ATRA, ATO, and chemotherapy is the standard of care for APL due to its high cure rates and low relapse rates.

questions.text: A 78-year-old patient is diagnosed with newly diagnosed AML but has significant comorbidities and is considered unfit for intensive induction chemotherapy ("7+3"). Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypomethylating agent (HMA) + Venetoclax

 

Option C:

 

The image indicates that for patients unfit for intensive chemotherapy, the combination of an HMA (e.g., azacitidine or decitabine) with venetoclax is the preferred treatment option.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Standard "7+3" induction chemotherapy: Standard "7+3" is too intensive for unfit patients.

 

Option B. Midostaurin + Gemtuzumab ozogamicin: Midostaurin and Gemtuzumab are often added to standard induction, not used in isolation for unfit patients.

 

Option D. Allogeneic stem cell transplant: Allogeneic stem cell transplant is a potential curative option but is generally not feasible for older patients with comorbidities.

 

Educational objective:

 

HMA + Venetoclax offers a less intensive, yet effective, treatment option for older or unfit AML patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal fullness. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows a leukocytosis with left shift. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BCR-ABL1

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, weight loss, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis with left shift, strongly suggests chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is the hallmark of CML and results from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. JAK2 V617F: Associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) like polycythemia vera (PV), essential thrombocythemia (ET), and primary myelofibrosis (PMF).

 

Option C. FLT3-ITD: More commonly associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Option D. t(15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of AML.

 

Educational objective:

 

BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is the diagnostic hallmark of CML.

choices.text: Constitutional symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss)
Normalization of the white blood cell count

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common feature of blast crisis in CML?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Normalization of the white blood cell count

 

In blast crisis, the white blood cell count usually remains elevated or increases further.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increasing splenomegaly: Blast cells can infiltrate the spleen, causing it to enlarge further.

 

Option B. Bone pain: Blast cells can also infiltrate the bone marrow, leading to bone pain.

 

Option C. Constitutional symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss): These are common symptoms of advanced CML and blast crisis due to the underlying malignancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Blast crisis is a serious complication of CML, and it is important to recognize its clinical features.

choices.text: Complete blood count (CBC) with differential

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal fullness. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Which of the following tests is the MOST appropriate initial diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Complete blood count (CBC) with differential

 

Option D:

 

The initial evaluation of suspected CML typically starts with a CBC with differential. This can reveal leukocytosis with a left shift (increased immature granulocytes) and often increased basophils, which are characteristic features of CML.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bone marrow biopsy: While a bone marrow biopsy is eventually needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess response to therapy, it's not the initial step.

 

Option B. Flow cytometry: Flow cytometry is helpful for further characterization of the leukemia cells, but not the initial diagnostic test.

 

Option C. Cytogenetic analysis (karyotype): This is important to confirm the Philadelphia chromosome translocation, but CBC is done first.

 

Educational objective:

 

CBC with differential is the first-line test in suspected CML due to its ability to detect characteristic hematologic abnormalities.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) t(9;22) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome)

 

Option C:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the t(9;22) translocation, is the characteristic genetic abnormality found in virtually all cases of CML.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. JAK2 V617F mutation: This mutation is associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), not CML.

 

Option B. t(15;17) translocation: This translocation is the hallmark of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

 

Option D. t(8;21) translocation: This translocation is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Educational objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome is the defining genetic feature of CML.

choices.text: Increase the dose of imatinib

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient with CML in chronic phase has been on imatinib for 3 years and now has rising BCR-ABL1 transcripts. Genetic testing reveals a T315I mutation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Initiate ponatinib

 

Option D:

 

Ponatinib is the only TKI with activity against the T315I mutation, making it the most appropriate choice in this scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of imatinib: Increasing the dose of imatinib will not be effective because the T315I mutation confers resistance to this drug and other first and second-generation TKIs.

 

Option B. Switch to dasatinib: Dasatinib is a second-generation TKI, but it is not effective against the T315I mutation.

 

Option C. Switch to nilotinib: Nilotinib is another second-generation TKI that is not effective against the T315I mutation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ponatinib is a third-generation TKI specifically designed to overcome TKI resistance, especially due to the T315I mutation.

choices.text: It is a first-line therapy for chronic phase CML.
It is used in the treatment of accelerated phase CML.
It is contraindicated in patients with blastic phase CML.
It is used at a higher dose in patients who are resistant or intolerant to prior TKI therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a correct statement regarding nilotinib in CML?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a first-line therapy for chronic phase CML.

 

Option A:

 

While nilotinib is a potent TKI used in CML, it is not the first-line therapy. Imatinib remains the first-line treatment for newly diagnosed chronic phase CML due to its long-term efficacy and safety profile.

 

Educational objective:

 

Nilotinib is a second-generation TKI used in CML patients resistant or intolerant to imatinib

questions.text: Which of the following is more commonly associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) than acute myeloid leukemia (AML)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphadenopathy

 

Option B:

 

Lymphadenopathy is more commonly observed in ALL, particularly in T-cell ALL, as the malignant cells can infiltrate lymph nodes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatosplenomegaly: While hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen) can be seen in both ALL and AML, it is not a distinguishing feature between the two. Both conditions can cause infiltration of these organs by leukemic cells.

 

Option C. Gingival hyperplasia: This is a rare finding in both ALL and AML, but it is more commonly associated with acute monocytic leukemia (a subtype of AML).

 

Option D. Skin infiltration: Skin infiltration (leukemia cutis) can occur in both ALL and AML, but it is relatively uncommon in both.

 

Educational objective:

 

While both ALL and AML can involve extramedullary sites, lymphadenopathy is more characteristic of ALL.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and gingival bleeding. Peripheral blood smear shows myeloblasts with Auer rods. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) t(15;17)

 

Option B:

 

The presence of Auer rods strongly suggests acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of AML. t(15;17) translocation is the hallmark cytogenetic abnormality in APL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(9;22): This translocation is the hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

 

Option C. inv(16): This inversion is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with eosinophilia, not APL.

 

Option D. t(8;21): This translocation is associated with a favorable-risk subtype of AML, but not APL.

 

Educational objective:

 

Auer rods are highly specific for APL, and the presence of this cytogenetic abnormality (t(15;17)) is diagnostic for APL.

questions.text: Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is associated with a high risk of relapse in AML?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) -5/del(5q)

 

Option D:

 

Monosomy 5 or deletion of the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q-) is associated with a poor prognosis in AML and a high risk of relapse.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. inv(16): This inversion is associated with acute myeloid leukemia with abnormal eosinophils (AML M4Eo) and generally has a favorable prognosis.

 

Option B. t(15;17): This translocation is the hallmark of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of AML. APL has a good prognosis when treated promptly with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (ATO).

 

Option C. t(8;21): This translocation is associated with acute myeloid leukemia with maturation (AML M2) and also has a relatively favorable prognosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cytogenetic abnormalities can significantly impact prognosis and treatment choices in AML.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations would make an IDH inhibitor a potential treatment option for an AML patient who is ineligible for HMA therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IDH1/IDH2

 

Option C:

 

The image mentions that IDH inhibitors can be used in cases of IDH mutations if the patient is not a candidate for HMA therapy.

 

Educational objective:

 

IDH inhibitors are targeted therapies for AML with specific IDH mutations.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with Down syndrome presents with pallor, fatigue, and bruising. Bone marrow biopsy shows megakaryoblastic proliferation and fibrosis. Which of the following leukemia subtypes is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL)

 

Option C:

 

The presentation of cytopenias, bone marrow fibrosis, and megakaryoblastic proliferation in a young child with Down syndrome strongly suggests AMKL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): While ALL is the most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome, it doesn't usually present with the specific bone marrow findings described here (megakaryoblastic proliferation and fibrosis).

 

Option B. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): This is too broad of a category. While AMKL is a subtype of AML, it has distinct features that differentiate it from other AML subtypes.

 

Option D. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML): JMML is another myeloid leukemia that can occur in young children, but it is not specifically associated with Down syndrome and usually presents with different bone marrow findings (monocytic proliferation).

 

Educational objective:

 

AMKL is a specific type of AML associated with Down syndrome and GATA1 mutations.
